title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
This course provides an introduction to the theory and practice of investments.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Understand fundamental investment concepts
Analyze risk and return of investment portfolios
Apply quantitative methods to investment decisions

title: Lecture 2: Pre-class Reading
text:
Please complete the following reading before class:

Chapter 2: Risk and Return
Focus on the mathematical foundations





Expected Return: The probability-weighted average of possible returns.
Variance: A measure of the dispersion of returns around the expected value.
Standard Deviation: The square root of variance; a common measure of risk.
Diversification: The strategy of reducing risk by investing in multiple assets.




Expected Return: \[E(R) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i \cdot R_i\]
Variance: \[\sigma^2 = \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i \cdot (R_i - E(R))^2\]




Why is standard deviation a useful measure of risk?
How does diversification reduce portfolio risk?

title: Lecture 2: Pre-class Reading
text:
Please complete the following reading before class:

Chapter 2: Risk and Return
Focus on the mathematical foundations





Expected Return: The probability-weighted average of possible returns.
Variance: A measure of the dispersion of returns around the expected value.
Standard Deviation: The square root of variance; a common measure of risk.
Diversification: The strategy of reducing risk by investing in multiple assets.




Expected Return: \[E(R) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i \cdot R_i\]
Variance: \[\sigma^2 = \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i \cdot (R_i - E(R))^2\]




Why is standard deviation a useful measure of risk?
How does diversification reduce portfolio risk?

title: Lecture 2: Lab
text:
In this lab, you will:

Calculate expected returns for a portfolio
Measure portfolio risk using variance and standard deviation
Explore the benefits of diversification





Use the provided dataset with multiple stock returns
Complete the calculations for each exercise
Interpret your results




Exercise 1: Calculate the expected return for each stock in the dataset.
Exercise 2: Compute the variance and standard deviation for each stock.
Exercise 3: Create a two-asset portfolio and calculate its expected return and risk.
Exercise 4: Vary the portfolio weights and observe how risk changes.



Submit your completed lab by the deadline posted on the schedule.

title: Lecture 1: Lab
text:
In this lab, you will:

Learn to access financial data sources
Calculate basic return statistics
Visualize stock price data





Download the sample dataset from the course materials
Open the data in your preferred analysis tool
Complete the exercises below




Exercise 1: Calculate the daily returns for the provided stock data.
Exercise 2: Compute the mean and standard deviation of returns.
Exercise 3: Create a time series plot of the stock prices.



Submit your completed lab by the deadline posted on the schedule.

title: Lecture 1: Pre-class Reading
text:
Please complete the following reading before class:

Chapter 1: Introduction to Investments
Review the key terms and concepts





Investment: The commitment of current resources in the expectation of deriving future benefits.
Financial Assets: Claims to the income generated by real assets.
Risk-Return Tradeoff: The principle that higher potential returns come with higher risk.





What motivates individuals to invest?
How do financial markets contribute to economic efficiency?
